t: Job 24
Job Says God Seems to Ignore Wrongs
“Why*pn are times not stored up by the Almighty, And*ln why do those who know Him not see His days?
Some*ln remove the landmarks; They*ln seize and devour flocks.
They*ln drive away the donkeys of the orphans; They*ln take the widow’s ox for a pledge.
They*ln push the needy aside from the road; The*ln poor of the land are made to hide themselves altogether.
Behold,*ln as wild donkeys in the wilderness They*ln go forth seeking food in their activity, As*ln bread for their*i children in the desert.
They*ln harvest their fodder in the field And*ln glean the vineyard of the wicked.
They*ln spend the night naked, without clothing, And*ln have no covering against the cold.
They*ln are wet with the mountain rains And*ln hug the rock for want of a shelter.
Others*ln snatch the orphan from the breast, And*ln against the poor they take a pledge.
They*ln cause the*i poor*i to go about naked without clothing, And*ln they take away the sheaves from the hungry.
Within*ln the walls they produce oil; They*ln tread wine presses but thirst.
From*ln the city men groan, And*ln the souls of the wounded cry out; Yet*ln God does not pay attention to folly.
“Others*ln have been with those who rebel against the light; They*ln do not want to know its ways Nor*ln abide in its paths.
The*ln murderer arises at dawn; He*ln kills the poor and the needy, And*ln at night he is as a thief.
The*ln eye of the adulterer waits for the twilight, Saying,*ln ‘No eye will see me.’ And*ln he disguises his face.
In*ln the dark they dig into houses, They*ln shut themselves up by day; They*ln do not know the light.
For*ln the morning is the same to him as thick darkness, For*ln he is familiar with the terrors of thick darkness.
“They*ln are insignificant on the surface of the water; Their*ln portion is cursed on the earth. They*ln do not turn toward the vineyards.
Drought*ln and heat consume the snow waters, So*iln does*i Sheol those*i who*i have sinned.
A*ln mother will forget him; The*ln worm feeds sweetly till he is no longer remembered. And*ln wickedness will be broken like a tree.
He*ln wrongs the barren woman And*ln does no good for the widow.
But*ln He drags off the valiant by His power; He*ln rises, but no one has assurance of life.
He*ln provides them with security, and they are supported; And*ln His eyes are on their ways.
They*ln are exalted a little while, then they are gone; Moreover,*ln they are brought low and like everything gathered up; Even*ln like the heads of grain they are cut off.
Now*ln if it is not so, who can prove me a liar, And*ln make my speech worthless?”
